ï»¿{"items":[{"tags":["javascript","python","ruby","web-browser","frontend"],"owner":{"reputation":14080,"user_id":224922,"user_type":"registered","accept_rate":94,"profile_image":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/0cd3969d4631c7ef1da736d816f1af72?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG","display_name":"never_had_a_name","link":"http://stackoverflow.com/users/224922/never-had-a-name"},"is_answered":true,"view_count":24330,"closed_date":1328768224,"accepted_answer_id":3722515,"answer_count":18,"score":144,"last_activity_date":1336753662,"creation_date":1284589693,"last_edit_date":1324322645,"question_id":3722334,"link":"http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3722334/why-dont-they-implement-python-and-ruby-in-the-web-browsers","closed_reason":"not constructive","title":"Why don't they implement Python and Ruby in the web browsers?","body":"

I wonder, why don't they implement other languages like Python and Ruby in the web browsers?

Don't they fit as client programming languages or did it just happen to be that JavaScript was the first one to be implemented, and they then kept on only supporting JavaScript because it just worked?

I mean... I really hate JavaScript compared to Ruby, no matter how hard I try to like it, as soon as I see Ruby code I want to cry for JavaScript for being so ugly.

Will there be no chance at all for Ruby and Python on the browser side (without having to use Silverlight) for the next 10 years?

"},{"tags":["javascript","python","ruby","performance","language-design"],"owner":{"reputation":2669,"user_id":3315,"user_type":"registered","accept_rate":89,"profile_image":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/f5ef71e8e7c154965adfc9c947d1899b?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG","display_name":"Greg Dan","link":"http://stackoverflow.com/users/3315/greg-dan"},"is_answered":true,"view_count":18570,"accepted_answer_id":5172833,"answer_count":7,"score":94,"last_activity_date":1372773905,"creation_date":1299075615,"last_edit_date":1301157138,"question_id":5168718,"link":"http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5168718/what-blocks-ruby-python-to-get-javascript-v8-speed","title":"What blocks Ruby, Python to get Javascript V8 speed?","body":"

Are there any Ruby / Python features that are blocking implementation of optimizations (e.g. inline caching) V8 engine has?

Python is co-developed by Google guys so it shouldn't be blocked by software patents.

Or this is rather matter of resources put into the V8 project by Google.

"},{"tags":["javascript","ruby-on-rails","ruby","heroku"],"owner":{"reputation":535,"user_id":761903,"user_type":"registered","accept_rate":60,"profile_image":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/63d51e025f46a3e37f700b9fa949eb25?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG","display_name":"WYi","link":"http://stackoverflow.com/users/761903/wyi"},"is_answered":true,"view_count":19915,"answer_count":4,"score":38,"last_activity_date":1339702768,"creation_date":1305914843,"last_edit_date":1305951871,"question_id":6075961,"link":"http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6075961/problem-deploying-rails-3-1-project-to-heroku-could-not-find-a-javascript-runti","title":"Problem deploying Rails 3.1 project to Heroku: Could not find a JavaScript runtime","body":"

> https://github.com/sstephenson/execjs
> for a list of available runtimes.

> /app/Rakefile:5 

> (See full trace by running task with --trace) 

> (in /app)

But I can successfully run the application locally, and I do have nodejs installed. Any idea why?

"},{"tags":["javascript","python","ruby","haskell","longest-prefix"],"owner":{"reputation":7219,"user_id":11687,"user_type":"registered","accept_rate":100,"profile_image":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/8f93a872e399bc1353cc8d4e791d5401?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG","display_name":"mislav","link":"http://stackoverflow.com/users/11687/mislav"},"is_answered":true,"view_count":8597,"accepted_answer_id":1917041,"answer_count":27,"score":36,"last_activity_date":1398866116,"creation_date":1260984166,"last_edit_date":1323007683,"question_id":1916218,"link":"http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1916218/find-the-longest-common-starting-substring-in-a-set-of-strings","title":"Find the longest common starting substring in a set of strings","body":"

This is a challenge to come up with the most elegant JavaScript, Ruby or other solution to a relatively trivial problem.

This problem is a more specific case of the Longest common substring problem. I need to only find the longest common starting substring in an array. This greatly simplifies the problem.

For example, the longest substring in [interspecies, interstelar, interstate] is "inters". However, I don't need to find "ific" in [specifics, terrific].

I've solved the problem by quickly coding up a solution in JavaScript as a part of my answer about shell-like tab-completion (test page here). Here is that solution, slightly tweaked:

function common_substring(data) {
  var i, ch, memo, idx = 0
  do {
    memo = null
    for (i=0; i < data.length; i++) {
      ch = data[i].charAt(idx)
      if (!ch) break
      if (!memo) memo = ch
      else if (ch != memo) break
    }
  } while (i == data.length && idx < data.length && ++idx)

  return (data[0] || '').slice(0, idx)
}

This code is available in this Gist along with a similar solution in Ruby. You can clone the gist as a git repo to try it out:

$ git clone git://gist.github.com/257891.git substring-challenge

I'm not very happy with those solutions. I have a feeling they might be solved with more elegance and less execution complexityâthat's why I'm posting this challenge.

I'm going to accept as an answer the solution I find the most elegant or concise. Here is for instance a crazy Ruby hack I come up withâdefining the & operator on String:

# works with Ruby 1.8.7 and above
class String
  def &(other)
    difference = other.to_str.each_char.with_index.find { |ch, idx|
      self[idx].nil? or ch != self[idx].chr
    }
    difference ? self[0, difference.last] : self
  end
end

class Array
  def common_substring
    self.inject(nil) { |memo, str| memo.nil? ? str : memo & str }.to_s
  end
end

Solutions in JavaScript or Ruby are preferred, but you can show off clever solution in other languages as long as you explain what's going on. Only code from standard library please.

Update: my favorite solutions

I've chosen the JavaScript sorting solution by kennebec as the "answer" because it struck me as both unexpected and genius. If we disregard the complexity of actual sorting (let's imagine it's infinitely optimized by the language implementation), the complexity of the solution is just comparing two strings.

Other great solutions:

  • "regex greed" by FM takes a minute or two to grasp, but then the elegance of it hits you. Yehuda Katz also made a regex solution, but it's more complex
  • commonprefix in Python â Roberto Bonvallet used a feature made for handling filesystem paths to solve this problem
  • Haskell one-liner is short as if it were compressed, and beautiful
  • the straightforward Ruby one-liner

Thanks for participating! As you can see from the comments, I learned a lot (even about Ruby).

"},{"tags":["javascript","jquery","ruby","haml"],"owner":{"reputation":193,"user_id":316929,"user_type":"registered","profile_image":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/ba5103035475cf0783d35f1be5f2fee8?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG","display_name":"Josh","link":"http://stackoverflow.com/users/316929/josh"},"is_answered":true,"view_count":28188,"accepted_answer_id":2641120,"answer_count":2,"score":34,"last_activity_date":1271281387,"creation_date":1271277535,"last_edit_date":1271279315,"question_id":2640863,"link":"http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2640863/ruby-methods-within-javascript-within-haml","title":"Ruby methods within Javascript within HAML","body":"

I have a jQuery script that adds a new field to a form, and this field contains dynamic information from an array. The problem is that I can't figure out how to add an array.each to populate the options of the select field within the javascript without breaking the HAML indentation and causing errors.

Here is my best attempt that does not work:

%script(type="text/javascript")  
  $('#mylink').click(function() {  
  $('#mylink').after('<select>  
  - myarray.each do |options|  
     <option value="#{options.id}">#{options.name}</option>  
  </select>);  
  )};

Also tried it with the :javascript filter with no luck.

"},{"tags":["javascript","ruby-on-rails","ruby"],"owner":{"reputation":6296,"user_id":430254,"user_type":"registered","accept_rate":87,"profile_image":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/c904c5e2712ece48bdc5f7cbabcfa58c?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG","display_name":"Valentin Vasilyev","link":"http://stackoverflow.com/users/430254/valentin-vasilyev"},"is_answered":true,"view_count":20379,"accepted_answer_id":602192,"answer_count":5,"score":29,"last_activity_date":1395269503,"creation_date":1235997023,"question_id":602147,"link":"http://stackoverflow.com/questions/602147/javascript-file-per-view-in-rails","title":"JavaScript file per view in Rails","body":"

As per 'unobtrusive JavaScript' recommendations I want to separate my JavaScript logic into
separate files. However I don't know how to organize them.

Should I:

  1. Just throw all application javascript into Application.js file and load it with layout page? This is simple approach but I will end up with a bloated Application.js. Some users might want to visit only a couple of pages, but this entire file would preloaded which is not good.
  2. Or should I create a separate javaScript file for each view and load them independently? This creates a set of questions. How to link each js file to corresponding view?

Thanks.

"},{"tags":["javascript","jquery","ruby-on-rails","ruby","unobtrusive-javascript"],"owner":{"reputation":25398,"user_id":216513,"user_type":"registered","accept_rate":85,"profile_image":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/30a45c64b2ef288f7ec098c5fb353a22?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG","display_name":"nathanvda","link":"http://stackoverflow.com/users/216513/nathanvda"},"is_answered":true,"view_count":2592,"accepted_answer_id":2891894,"answer_count":3,"score":27,"last_activity_date":1331455738,"creation_date":1274614279,"last_edit_date":1274621407,"question_id":2891523,"link":"http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2891523/rails-best-practices-where-to-place-unobtrusive-javascript","title":"rails best practices where to place unobtrusive javascript","body":"

my rails applications (all 2.3.5) use a total mix of inline javascript, rjs, prototype and jquery. Let's call it learning or growing pains. Lately i have been more and more infatuated with unobtrusive javascript. It makes your html clean, in the same way css cleaned it up.

But most examples i have seen are small examples, and they put all javascript(jquery) inside application.js

Now i have a pretty big application, and i am thinking up ways to structure my js. I like somehow that my script is still close to the view, so i am thinking something like

orders.html.erb
orders.js

where orders.js contains the unobtrusive javascript specific to that view. But maybe that's just me being too conservative :)

I have read some posts by Yehuda Katz about this very problem here and here, where he tackles this problem. It will go through your js-files and only load those relevant to your view. But alas i can't find a current implementation.

So my questions:

  • how do you best structure your unobtrusive javascript; manage your code, how do you make sure that it is obvious from the html what something is supposed to do. I guess good class names go a long way :)
  • how do you arrange your files, load them all in? just a few? do you use content_for :script or javascript_include_tag in your view to load the relevant scripts. Or ... ?
  • do you write very generic functions (like a delete), with parameters (add extra attributes?), or do you write very specific functions (DRY?). I know in Rails 3 there is a standard set, and everything is unobtrusive there. But how to start in Rails 2.3.5?

In short: what are the best practices for doing unobtrusive javascript in rails? :)

"},{"tags":["javascript","ruby","metaprogramming"],"owner":{"reputation":6747,"user_id":310291,"user_type":"registered","accept_rate":69,"profile_image":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/22184b90539c866099c39872b3c12a0e?s=128&d=identicon&r=PG","display_name":"user310291","link":"http://stackoverflow.com/users/310291/user310291"},"is_answered":true,"view_count":3797,"accepted_answer_id":9779904,"answer_count":6,"score":25,"last_activity_date":1359476253,"creation_date":1332201022,"last_edit_date":1332203429,"question_id":9779624,"link":"http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9779624/does-javascript-have-something-like-rubys-method-missing-feature","title":"Does Javascript have something like Ruby's method_missing feature?","body":"

In Ruby I think you can call a method that hasn't been defined and yet capture the name of the method called and do processing of this method at runtime.

Can Javascript do the same kind of thing ?

"}],"has_more":true,"quota_max":10000,"quota_remaining":9778}
